byline.contributor: Mujib Mashal reported from Kabul, and Taimoor Shah from Kandahar, Afghanistan. Salman Masood and Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud contributed reporting from Islamabad, Pakistan, and Zia ur-Rehman from Karachi.
byline.original: By MUJIB MASHAL and TAIMOOR SHAH

abstract: Taliban is faced with having to elect new supreme leader for second time in less than year following death of leader Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour in American drone strike in Pakistan; group's subdued response during meetings to discuss replacement reflects growing sense of vulnerability in Pakistani havens; several Taliban commanders say they anticipate confirmation of new leader to be fraught process, while some welcome chance to elect less divisive figure.
lead_paragraph: The effort to replace the leader killed in an American drone strike comes amid concerns over safety, intensifying divisions and access to money.

headline.main: Shaken, Taliban Begin Effort to Replace Dead Leader, Mullah Mansour
headline.print_headline: Shaken, Taliban Begin Searching for New Leader

snippet: The effort to replace the leader killed in an American drone strike comes amid concerns over safety, intensifying divisions and access to money.
